awd_titl_txt: GEM: Particle Acceleration by Foreshock Transients
awd_abstract_narration:
Shocks accelerate particles to relativistic speeds throughout the universe – in astrophysical processes and more locally in the region of space near the Earth. It is a mystery how shocks can accelerate particles to energies higher than their own shock potential energy reserve. This project will investigate irregularities in plasma flows ahead of shocks moving into the magnetosphere, studying plasma bubbles and hot flow anomalies. The results of this project have direct applications in space weather models; it thus addresses one of the goals set out in the National Space Weather Action Plan. The project will also help understand shock acceleration throughout the universe. Three early career researchers and a graduate student will receive support.

The key objectives are (i) to determine the role of upstream electron energization on space weather phenomena that result from inward penetration of energetic particles; and (ii) to provide new insights in the classic pre-acceleration need for Fermi type shock acceleration processes. For the first time high quality and resolution THEMIS and MMS data from the foreshock region are available. THEMIS provides data on large scale magnetic structures along with high-frequency magnetic fluctuations and superthermal particles ( >25 keV), while MMS is capable of resolving small scale (10-100 km) high time resolution (30 -150 ms) providing microscale and electron dynamics quantities. The observations will be supplemented by Cluster and DMSP which monitor the energetic particle flux in the cusp and from all sky imagers and NSF-funded SuperDARN data providing signatures of accelerating particles. Combining these observations is a challenging task. The proposal utilizes a well-tested 3D global hybrid simulation code to organize the data and achieve the desired results.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
When the solar wind encounters the Earth’s bow shock, most of the solar wind ions are decelerated and heated, whereas a few of them have to return upstream forming a region called the ion foreshock. In the ion foreshock, there are many transient structures named foreshock transients frequently observed by spacecraft. Previous studies found that these foreshock transients can accelerate particles which can potentially harm electronic instruments and astronauts, so our project focus on understanding the acceleration mechanisms and their impacts. Below we summarize our findings.

(1)   Using high resolution spacecraft observations in comparison with numerical simulations, we found that sub-ion scale magnetic reconnection can occur within foreshock transients, which transfers energy from magnetic field to electrons. Within foreshock transients, there are also sub-ion scale magnetic holes which can modify the electron energy and pitch angles.

(2)   We found that whistler waves within foreshock transients can resonate with electrons. Our statistical study shows that whistler waves are common inside foreshock transients and ~15% of them have wave amplitude large enough to nonlinearly resonate with and accelerate electrons.

(3)   Using ARTEMIS observations at lunar orbit, we found that the electron heating is continuous when foreshock transients propagate from dayside to the midtail foreshock (X~-50 RE) based on case studies and statistical studies. We also found that the electron temperature increase is associated with the ion kinetic energy decrease, suggesting that there could be energy transfer from ions to electrons. Therefore, the electron heating could partly come from the macroscale formation and evolution of the transient structures.

(4)   Using numerical simulations, we revealed the kinetic formation process of foreshock transients and determined how the electrons, solar wind ions, and foreshock ions transfer energy through the electric field, which was confirmed by spacecraft observations. When the foreshock ions encounter a sudden jump of magnetic field, they perform partial gyration different from electrons leading to a current. This current is responsible for the magnetic field profile of foreshock transients and energy transfer. We are thus capable of quantifying the whole process and therefore establishing predictive models so that we can forecast their impacts.  

(5)   We derived analytical models of foreshock ion-driven current and derived expansion speed models based on the energy transfer through the current against the induced electric field. We compare and improve our models based on simulations and observations. We then conducted a statistical study showing that our model can moderately predict the perturbations driven by foreshock transients. After a predictive model of foreshock ions is established, our models will become fully predictive by only using the upstream parameters as input, e.g., solar wind data at L1.

In summary, using spacecraft observations and numerical simulations, we have identified multiple acceleration mechanisms within foreshock transients and examined the energy budget between the fields and different plasma populations. These results suggest that foreshock transients can enhance the acceleration efficiency of shock acceleration and provide seed populations to initiate the shock acceleration. Shock acceleration is an important source of energetic particles throughout the universe, which creates critical hazards to our space environment. We established predictive models of foreshock transients which can be used to forecast the contribution from foreshock transients to particle acceleration at the Earth’s bow shock. Additionally, although foreshock transients have been observed at planetary bow shocks, whether they exist at other shock environments is difficult to determine because they can only be in-situ observed. With our models, we can predict the existence of foreshock transients given any shock environment so that we can couple foreshock transients into shock acceleration models.
